page.lettertext:
fol.220r
M
r
Bodley: Her
Ma
tie
hath ben acquainted w
th
yo
r
dispatch of the
xxvj
th
of Novembre; wherin thoughe shee doth fynde howe acceptable it
is to
Thestates,
that shee suspendeth her demaund
: yet can she not remaine
satisfied her selfe w
th
this manner of thir proceeding, wherin the worlde
must need
perceave That their respect to her present occasions is farre
short of hers toward
them in the tymes of their greatest necessities.
And therfore althoughe her Ma
tie
is pleased, That yo
w
doe lett them
knowe, that shee (out of her love to their estate) is not disposed nowe to
Contest w
th
them, but will forbeare to doe any thing, w
ch
might serve
for cullour of any disordre or Confusion to aryse amongst them at this
Tyme, when there are so many devises used to gaine the Populer w
th
fraudulent offere of Peace; yet would shee have yo
w
let them knowe
That this their colde proceeding w
th
her, must need
leave coldnesse in
her disposic
o
n, or alyenac
o
n from them, whose good she hath preferred
before so many particuler Considerac
o
ns of her owne. And therfore,
for the matter of shipping, of w
ch
in their owne l
re
s presented by
M
r
Caron
they make promyse; yo
w
must let them knowe, That her Ma
tie
lookes assuredly for the performance, as a thing wherof in no wise they
must make default, because it will breed great confusion in her Ma
t
owne Preparac
o
ns: But for
e sending of their deputies shee would
have them playnelie tolde, That except their meaning be at the tyme
of their comming (beside their formallytie of thancksgivinge) to
make her Ma
tie
some such overture of present satisfaccion, as
may stand w
th
her honor to receave, wherin her May
tie
wilbe
content to admytt the Considerac
o
n of
e circumstanc
, w
ch
in reasone
they can alleage for not performance of the former Proportion of
her demaund
, shee shall rather take their publycke comming as a
multiplicac
o
n of further scorne, then any kind of honorable satisfacc
o
n
And therfore she is pleased yow shall returne to
e generall bodye of
Thestat
, this aunswere formerly sett downe: But forasmuchas none
can better deale inwardly, and pryvately w
th
Mons
r
Barnevill
then yo
wr
selfe, Her Ma
tie
would have yo
w
intymate unto him, That
howesoever her May
tie
may be content externallie to digest this manner
fol.220v
of dealing for the tyme, because the Co
m
on Enemy shal[l not make]
his particular advantage of any drynesse betwene the Q[ueene and]
them; yet can it not but worke some Impression of unkyndn[ess in her]
Ma
t
princely brest, w
ch
wyll beake out at one tyme or o[ther, and]
therfore to advyse him, as a good Patryott to them, and a [wellwiller]
to the Co
m
on cause, to worke them to some better fashion: [whom yow]
may assure That if they shall come over presently w
th
p[ower to]
offer as good a Project at the least, or a better if it m[ay be,]
then that w
ch
he delivered yo
w
at yo
r
last Returne, That [in suche]
case both shee will particulerly have sence of his good affec[tion and]
can be contented that they shall send their deputies, who[m shee will]
favourably receave as messeng
rs
from her frynd
, and ne[ighbours,]
at w
ch
tyme yo
w
may ether Returne in their company or som[e fewe]
dayes before
em, as yo
w
see cause. Her may
tie
hath in this [forme given]
lyke aunswere to their Agent, who I doubt not will cleare[ly and]
particulerly Relate
e same.
Her Ma
tie
wroate of late hir l
re
s both to the States g[eneral and]
to the
States of Zeland
uppon the ernest request of
S
r
[Robert]
Sidneie
, that theie would give order to furnishe the [garrison]
of
Flusshinge
w
th
powder and repaire their owne M[agazine]
[.] [.], as by spetiall Article in the Contrac[t .]
[.] [.] whearein whither S
r
Rob ert Sidneie [.]
delt w
th
yowe to further his suite, I doe not knowe [.]
I wishe that yowe would inquire of the deliverye of th[.]
and to use all the meanes yowe can to have the same [.]
speedelie satisfied, for that in trewthe hir Ma
tie
hath [.]
thowght that hir masse of powder that was laid theare [.]
showld have been expended by the garrison, but semeth [.]
w
th
M
r
Sidneie, for expendinge of the same, w
th
owt [.]
to be made by the States: and hearein S
r
Robert Sidneie [.]
thinke himself much beholdinge to yowe, if yowe can [.]
the states to satisfie his request.
My sicknes of late tyme, hath bene
e cause
t
I have not w[ritten to]
yow, as I was accustomed nor yet to
M
r
Gylp
y
, wher[by I]
pray yow to tak the same for a just excuse.
Fr
o
e Cowrt at Rychm
o
t xv xbr 1595.
Your assured loving frend William Burghely
